articles.headline: Senate Passes Start-Ups Bill, With Amendments
articles.snippet: The Jump-start Our Business Start-ups, or JOBS, Act is meant to ease rules to create jobs and raise financing for small companies.
articles.abstract: The Jump-start Our Business Start-ups, or JOBS, Act is meant to ease rules to create jobs and raise financing for small companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Depending on who is speaking, a bill approved by the Senate on Thursday to make it easier for small companies to raise money will either improve the economy by creating jobs or cause unwitting investors to get swindled.

articles.headline: As Young Lose Interest in Cars, G.M. Turns to MTV for Help
articles.snippet: The goal is to solve one of the most vexing problems facing the car industry: many young consumers today do not care that much about cars.
articles.abstract: The goal is to solve one of the most vexing problems facing the car industry: many young consumers today do not care that much about cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ross Martin, 37, is a published poet and a former drummer in an alternative rock band. Wearing Nike high tops and loosefitting jeans, he is the kind of figure who wouldn’t attract a second glance on the streets of Brooklyn, where he lives.

articles.headline: U.S. Inches Toward Goal of Energy Independence
articles.snippet: Declining oil consumption and new energy production have brought the United States closer to a goal that has tantalized presidents since Richard Nixon.
articles.abstract: Declining oil consumption and new energy production have brought the United States closer to a goal that has tantalized presidents since Richard Nixon.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDLAND, Tex. — The desolate stretch of West Texas desert known as the Permian Basin is still the lonely domain of scurrying roadrunners by day and howling coyotes by night. But the roar of scores of new oil rigs and the distinctive acrid fumes of drilling equipment are unmistakable signs that crude is gushing again.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Tibetan Self-Immolations Rise as China Tightens Grip
articles.snippet: The authorities in Beijing, alarmed about the threat to stability in a region seething with discontent over religious and cultural controls, have responded with heavy-handed measures.
articles.abstract: The authorities in Beijing, alarmed about the threat to stability in a region seething with discontent over religious and cultural controls, have responded with heavy-handed measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAQU, China — Like many children of Tibetan nomads, Tsering Kyi started school relatively late, at age 10, but by all accounts she made up for lost time by studying with zeal.

articles.headline: Tax Policy: Much Talk, Few Details
articles.snippet: Politicians talk about lowering tax rates, but they rarely mention which tax preferences should be cut to maintain the same level of government revenue.
articles.abstract: Politicians talk about lowering tax rates, but they rarely mention which tax preferences should be cut to maintain the same level of government revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: If approached the right way, there could actually be some widespread agreement on tax reform coming out of the current election.

articles.headline: U.S. Relaxes Limits on Use of Data in Terror Analysis
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. signed new guidelines on how analysts may access, store and search information gathered by government agencies about Americans.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. signed new guidelines on how analysts may access, store and search information gathered by government agencies about Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is moving to relax restrictions on how counterterrorism analysts may retrieve, store and search information about Americans gathered by government agencies for purposes other than national security threats.

articles.headline: Drug Dosage Was Approved Despite Warning
articles.snippet: The Alzheimer’s drug Aricept 23 was set to lose its patent, but its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusivity.
articles.abstract: The Alzheimer’s drug Aricept 23 was set to lose its patent, but its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four months before a best-selling Alzheimer’s drug was set to lose its patent protection, its makers received approval for a higher dosage that extended their exclusive right to sell the drug. But the higher dosage caused potentially dangerous side effects and worked only slightly better than the existing drugs, according to an article published Thursday in the British Medical Journal.

articles.headline: Hip Device Phaseout Followed F.D.A. Data Request
articles.snippet: Shortly after getting a request from the Food and Drug Administration for safety data about an artificial hip, Johnson & Johnson executives decided to discontinue making the device.
articles.abstract: Shortly after getting a request from the Food and Drug Administration for safety data about an artificial hip, Johnson & Johnson executives decided to discontinue making the device.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson executives decided in 2009 to phase out a hip implant and sell off its inventories for use in patients just weeks after the Food and Drug Administration asked the company in a letter for added safety data about the implant, administration documents and corporate records show.

articles.headline: Obama Seizes Chance to Score as an Everyman
articles.snippet: Basketball provides an opportunity to exploit what the Obama campaign regards as the president’s advantage over Mitt Romney in the battle over which candidate can seem more “ordinary.”
articles.abstract: Basketball provides an opportunity to exploit what the Obama campaign regards as the president’s advantage over Mitt Romney in the battle over which candidate can seem more “ordinary.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama loves basketball, as everyone is reminded in March — especially in an election year in which he has been jumping through you-know-whats to assert as much.

articles.headline: College President Is Obama’s Pick for World Bank Chief
articles.snippet: The White House on Friday named Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College and a global health expert, as its nominee to lead the World Bank.
articles.abstract: The White House on Friday named Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College and a global health expert, as its nominee to lead the World Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday named Jim Yong Kim, the president of Dartmouth College and a global health expert, as its nominee to lead the World Bank.
